author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Voluntary Tax
description: A scoop highlights the details behind the low tax rates on the wealthy.
content: It’s been a back-and-forth struggle over the course of American history: How much tax should the wealthy pay?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: G.M. agrees to tighter federal restrictions aimed at combating climate change.
description: The tighter fuel economy and tailpipe pollution rules are along the lines of what California has already agreed to with five other auto companies.
content: General Motors on Wednesday told the Biden administration that it would agree to tighter federal fuel economy and tailpipe pollution rules, along the lines of what California has already agreed to with five other auto companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: U.S. Weighs Possibility of Airstrikes if Afghan Forces Face Crisis
description: The Pentagon is considering whether to intervene with warplanes or drones in the event that Kabul is in danger of falling to the Taliban, though no decisions have been made.
content: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon is considering seeking authorization to carry out airstrikes to support Afghan security forces if Kabul or another major city is in danger of falling to the Taliban, potentially introducing flexibility into President Biden’s plan to end the United States military presence in the conflict, senior officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Tenement Museum Makes Room for Black History
description: Reopening after a tumultuous year, this Lower East Side institution is addressing the omissions and erasures in the neighborhood’s history — and its own.
content: There is no shortage of ghosts at the Tenement Museum, which for nearly three decades has explored issues of immigration, home and belonging through tours of the meticulously recreated apartments in its five-story building on the Lower East Side. But in recent years, the story of one particularly ghostly presence has lingered in the background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Former Students Win Racial Profiling Case Against French State
description: Three young men filed a suit saying they had been discriminated against during ID checks in Paris in 2017, when they were high school students. An appeals court ruled in their favor this week.
content: PARIS — Three young men have won a yearslong legal battle against the French state after a court ruled they had been subject to discriminatory police checks in 2017, when they were high-school students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Melissa Eddy
title: In Germany, the key to everyday freedoms is a rapid virus test.
description: Want to go out for a meal indoors in Germany? Get a test. Want to stay at a hotel as a tourist or work out at the gym? Same answer.
content: Want to go out for a meal indoors in Germany? Get a test. Want to stay at a hotel as a tourist or work out at the gym? Same answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘In the Heights’ Review: In Dreams Begin Responsibilities
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s musical comes to the screen as an exuberant and heartfelt party, directed by Jon M. Chu and starring Anthony Ramos.
content: “In the Heights” begins with a man — Usnavi, played by Anthony Ramos — telling a story to a group of children. They are gathered on the patio of a bar on a palm-fringed, sun-kissed beach in the Dominican Republic. The bar is called El Sueñito, or the Little Dream, and the name is at once a clue, a spoiler and the key to the themes of this exuberant and heartfelt musical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: If You’ve Never Tried Growing Radicchio, Now Is the Time
description: This cultivated form of chicory is having a moment. Here’s what you need to know before you plant it.
content: Radicchio: Yes, it’s a thing at the moment. It has its own newly formed association, an annual festival and even a poster and lapel pin for sale on Etsy. Yet many American gardeners have never tried growing this cultivated form of chicory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: An Onscreen Chat With Hito Steyerl, Art’s Great Screen Skeptic
description: The German artist’s new exhibition at the Pompidou Center in Paris examines, with bitter humor, how digital technology shapes life offline.
content: If any artist can make sense of this sense-defying period, it would be Hito Steyerl: poet laureate of digital dislocation and social upheaval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Anton Troianovski
title: With a Ban on Navalny’s Group, Putin Sends Clear Message to Biden
description: The move, just a week before their summit, will likely push the Russian opposition further underground and was a signal that the country’s domestic affairs are not up for discussion.
content: MOSCOW — A Russian court on Wednesday designated Aleksei A. Navalny’s political movement as an extremist network, a remarkable move that sent a message to President Biden ahead of his meeting next week with President Vladimir V. Putin: Russian domestic affairs are not up for discussion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: A crucial vote in Israel.
content: Lawmakers in Israel will hold a vote of confidence on Sunday on a new coalition government, potentially ending the 12-year tenure of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: Search for Victims of the Tulsa Race Massacre Has Uncovered 27 Coffins
description: There are strong reasons to suspect that the mass grave was for victims of the 1921 killing, given contemporary evidence.
content: Last summer, after generations of silence and denial, the city of Tulsa, Okla., began excavations in search of the graves of victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre. Nearly a century had passed since a mob of white Tulsans violently invaded the prosperous Black neighborhood of Greenwood, overcoming a vigorous defense by some residents, killing and rounding up Black Tulsans en masse and burning much of the neighborhood to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri
title: The Masterpieces That Napoleon Stole, and How Some Went Back
description: His art seizures paved the way for similar French excesses in Africa a century later. Yet the return of some treasures after his defeat set a model for museums today.
content: PARIS — The spoils of war were positively magnificent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: More vaccines cannot come too soon for stricken regions, including Latin America, a W.H.O. official says.
description: Eight of the 10 countries with the highest rate of Covid deaths per capita are in Latin America and the Caribbean, where vaccines are sorely lacking.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Officials at the World Health Organization on Wednesday repeated their calls for the world’s governments to accelerate plans to distribute coronavirus vaccines to hard-hit nations, warning that many countries in Latin America continue to see rising caseloads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Carey
title: Rich Schools, Poor Schools and a Biden Plan
description: The way U.S. education is funded can widen disparities. A proposed $20 billion program seeks to even things out.
content: Can President Biden fix America’s inequitable public school funding?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Brewer
title: We’re Mississippi’s Last Abortion Clinic, and We’re Braced for the Worst
description: We’ve long needed federal intervention to protect abortion rights, but it’s never been more urgent.
content: JACKSON, Miss. — I could see the pain on the patient’s face as soon as she walked through the door of the abortion clinic where I work. She was unbearably sick from pregnancy complications and had been in and out of the hospital for weeks. She had just driven almost 200 miles to reach us because there are so few abortion clinics in the South. Like most of the patients who come through my clinic, she thought she’d be able to get an abortion that day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Najim Rahim and Mike Ives
title: Attack in Afghanistan Kills 10 From Charity That Clears Land Mines
description: The government blamed the Taliban for the attack on the British-American charity, the HALO Trust. The militant group denied any responsibility.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — At least 10 people were killed and 16 others wounded in an armed attack on staff members of a British-American charity in Afghanistan that has been clearing land mines in the country for decades, officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Exxon’s Board Defeat Signals the Rise of Social-Good Activists
description: The energy giant’s stunning loss was the work of a tiny hedge fund that believes investing for social good is also good for the bottom line.
content: Wall Street has seen its share of strange bedfellows, but a recent alliance of investors that took on Exxon Mobil was unprecedented.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: It’s Hard to Sue Gun Makers. New York Is Set to Change That.
description: State lawmakers passed a bill designed to get around a federal law giving gun manufacturers broad immunity from lawsuits, in hopes of cracking down on the smuggling of illegal weapons into New York.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — New York State lawmakers passed legislation on Tuesday intended to allow civil lawsuits to be brought against firearm manufacturers and dealers, an attempt to circumvent the broad immunity gun companies currently enjoy under federal law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler
title: A Tiny Spanish Island Where Pirates Once Roamed
description: There is no place to shop on Nueva Tabarca, scant cellphone reception and unreliable internet. To some, that is part of its appeal.
content: NUEVA TABARCA, Spain — As a teenager, Federico Mérimée dived for sea urchins on the tiny island of Nueva Tabarca. Back then, he and his friends couldn’t afford the fare for the water taxi, so they would hitch rides from the mainland on local fishing boats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: The City Awaits You. We’ve Got a Few Tips.
description: The Summer in the City newsletter has returned to guide you on making the most of New York again, whether you’re looking to get out in a crowd or escape from one.
content: After more than a year away from beaches, bar crawls and movies under the stars, vaccinated New Yorkers are ready to re-enter the world. To help readers maximize their summer fun — and stay on top of evolving public health guidance — The New York Times is reviving its weekly Summer in the City newsletter. Created in 2018 by Elisabeth Goodridge, now the deputy editor for Travel, and Jessica Anderson, deputy editorial director for newsletters, as a curated guide to summer fun for New Yorkers, the newsletter went on hiatus last year. But the new edition is now published every Wednesday, with event ideas through Labor Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Hagi
title: Rivka Galchen’s Historical Novel Satirizes Moral Panic
description: “Everyone Knows Your Mother Is a Witch” sets a literal witch hunt in 17th-century Germany.
content: EVERYONE KNOWS YOUR MOTHER IS A WITCH By Rivka Galchen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: All Together Now for Tribeca Festival’s 20th Anniversary Edition
description: After last year’s edition was postponed amid the pandemic, the event returns in person with a crowd-pleasing lineup brimming with stories of community.
content: Partway through “In the Heights,” the Tribeca Festival’s opening-night feature, a throng of Washington Heights neighbors sprawl about a courtyard during a heat wave. They loaf and grumble, until one woman steps in to start a barrio Carnaval of song and dance. Finding solidarity in nasty circumstances is a theme that flows through this year’s 20th anniversary festival, which begins Wednesday and runs through June 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Emily Cochrane
title: Collapse of Infrastructure Talks Puts Climate Action at Risk
description: The chances of pushing climate legislation through Congress, a long shot from the beginning, now appear even more uncertain.
content: WASHINGTON — The collapse of negotiations between President Biden and Senate Republicans for an infrastructure bill has complicated the prospects for another priority of the administration: fighting climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
title: Biden Aims to Bolster U.S. Alliances in Europe, but Challenges Loom
description: The good will President Biden brings on his first trip abroad papers over lingering doubts about U.S. reliability and the cost that Europe will be expected to pay.
content: WASHINGTON — It should not be that hard to be an American leader visiting Europe for the first time after President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: Crook’s Corner, a Landmark North Carolina Restaurant, Has Closed
description: It led the modern revival of Southern cuisine nearly 40 years ago, and remained a seedbed for talented chefs and new ideas.
content: Crook’s Corner, the restaurant in Chapel Hill, N.C., that helped spark a renaissance in Southern cuisine starting in the 1980s, has permanently closed, Shannon Healy, an owner, said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Iga Swiatek and Coco Gauff Eliminated in French Open Quarterfinals
description: For the first time in the Open era, all four women’s singles semifinalists have reached this stage for the first time at a Grand Slam tournament.
content: PARIS — It was the first Grand Slam singles quarterfinal match for both Coco Gauff and Barbora Krejcikova and, frankly, you could tell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Nun Stole Over $800,000 to Support Gambling Habit, Prosecutors Say
description: Sister Mary Margaret Kreuper has agreed to plead guilty to charges that she embezzled the money while she was the principal at a Catholic school in Torrance, Calif., prosecutors said.
content: As a Catholic nun, Sister Mary Margaret Kreuper had taken a vow of poverty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Wisconsin Pharmacist Who Tampered With Vaccine Gets 3-Year Sentence
description: The pharmacist, Steven R. Brandenburg, believed in conspiracy theories and thought vaccines were dangerous, the authorities said.
content: A hospital pharmacist who pleaded guilty to trying to spoil more than 500 doses of a Covid-19 vaccine was sentenced on Tuesday to three years in prison, federal prosecutors in Wisconsin announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
title: The War of the Weary
description: Soccer’s biggest stars have been playing almost nonstop for a year. Over the next month, major tournaments like Euro 2020 may be decided by which ones have the most left in the tank.
content: LONDON — A couple of weeks ago, as the players who will represent Wales in this summer’s European soccer championships started to report for duty, their coaching staff instituted an unwritten rule: Try, if at all possible, not to mention the F word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Michael D. Shear
title: In Britain, Biden called diplomacy and alliances vital to the world’s future.
description: In his first overseas trip as president, Mr. Biden said no nation can solve its problems alone, and that democracies must prove that their way is better than autocracy.
content: R.A.F. MILDENHALL, England — President Biden began his first overseas trip by telling American troops in Britain that the future of the world depends on restoring the longstanding alliances with European countries that have been “hardened in the fire of war” and built by “generations of Americans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Gun Makers Could Be Sued More Easily Under New York Bill
description: New legislation would allow civil lawsuits against  manufacturers and dealers who make or sell guns illegally or inappropriately.

title: Yankees Break Out of Offensive Funk in Win Over Twins
description: Gary Sanchez and Miguel Andujar both homered for the Yankees. The Mets, meanwhile, got crushed by Baltimore.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Gary Sanchez and Miguel Andujar homered, D.J. LeMahieu had two hits and an R.B.I., as the Yankees beat the Minnesota Twins, 8-4, Tuesday night to end a four-game skid.

title: A U.S. solar company will build a new factory in Ohio, giving Biden a boost.
description: First Solar will invest $680 million for the new plant, and is expected to add 500 jobs.

description: The Orange County community may lack the ‘cool factor’ of other parts of the Hudson Valley, but residents are fine with that.
content: To understand the appeal of Warwick, N.Y., an expansive town northwest of New York City, duck into an alley off Main Street called Carriage Path.

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The show must go on.
content: The pandemic hit the arts and culture industry harder than almost any other. During the past year, the unemployment rate for actors, singers and dancers has been higher than it has been even for restaurant employees or workers in other devastated industries. Theaters were quickly shuttered and widely expected to be the last places to reopen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Hall of Fame Delays Jeter’s Induction, but Now Will Allow Fans
description: The ceremony for Derek Jeter, Larry Walker, Ted Simmons and Marvin Miller will now be an event requiring tickets in September.
content: Call it Take 2.

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: In a New AMC Satire, a Sitcom Wife Gets the Last Laugh
description: Annie Murphy stars in a black comedy that spoofs corny family sitcoms while revealing the darkness behind the bright lights and bad jokes.
content: Shortly after the 2016 presidential election, Valerie Armstrong experienced what she described as “a feminist fit of rage.” So she put that rage into a comedy pilot, a pussy hat in script form.

author: By Rick Rojas and Mitch Smith
title: Despite Ample Shots and Incentives, Vaccine Rates Lag Far Behind in the South
description: Alabama, Louisiana and Mississippi have the lowest vaccination rates in the country, increasing the risk of virus surges there.
content: NASHVILLE — Public health departments have held vaccine clinics at churches. They have organized rides to clinics. Gone door to door. Even offered a spin around a NASCAR track for anyone willing to get a shot.

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Introverts Vs. Extroverts, a Family Feud
description: Please don’t make me stay at that party.
content: My husband has long had a greater appetite for socializing than I do; this was a semi-frequent clash of ours before the pandemic that was papered over during quarantine because nobody could go anywhere. It would come out in small ways as we were working in the same limited space (my husband likes to chat during the workday; I like to bury my face in a computer in a silent room), but mostly my preferences won out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yubelka Mendoza and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: In Nicaragua, Repression Deepens as More Opposition Leaders Are Detained
description: With a stunning wave of arrests of political opponents and civil society leaders, President Daniel Ortega will practically be unopposed in November elections.
content: MANAGUA, Nicaragua — Nicaraguan police have detained five prominent opposition figures in two days, accelerating a slide toward one-party rule.

title: Washington’s Daily Secret Machine
description: A White House correspondent examines a predecessor’s candid memo about how classified information is traded in the Beltway.
content: This article is part of a special report on the 50th anniversary of the Pentagon Papers.

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Shell says a court ruling on greenhouse gases will speed up its plans to cut emissions.
description: The oil giant is likely to appeal the judgment, the company’s chief executive said, but it also felt “a determination to rise to the challenge” posed by the court.
content: Royal Dutch Shell will respond to a recent defeat in a Dutch court by accelerating its efforts to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions, the company’s leader said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Health Care Workers Deserve Fashion, Too
description: After masks, medical scrubs get the designer treatment. It’s the next big market no one expected.
content: One of the more unexpected side effects of the pandemic was to forever alter our relationships with personal protective equipment; to make medical garments, at least in the mask sense, a new accessory of self-expression and a part of almost every wardrobe. And every designer’s arsenal.

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze and Melissa Eddy
title: Germany Makes Rapid Virus Tests a Key to Everyday Freedoms
description: As the country begins reopening, it is relying on widespread, free antigen tests to ensure that anyone not yet vaccinated against the coronavirus is also not infectious.
content: BERLIN — Want to go out for a meal indoors in Germany? Get a test. Want to stay at a hotel as a tourist or work out at the gym? Same answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: New Buildings Lure Tenants With Free Rent
description: To fill empty buildings, developers have been offering generous concessions, including up to five months of free rent.
content: Prepandemic, landlords often treated Megan McDonald like they were doing her a favor by renting her an apartment. But this spring, as Ms. McDonald, 29, began looking for her first place since Covid, new developments were essentially begging her to move in by offering some free rent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: It’s Nadal vs. Djokovic in the French Open, but One Round Early
description: Rafael Nadal, the 13-time champion at Roland Garros, is set for yet another showdown with Novak Djokovic, the world No. 1 and his longtime rival. But the title won’t be on the line.
content: PARIS — Roland Garros came alive Wednesday in so many ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bee Shapiro
title: Debbie Gibson Is Not Going to Get Stuck in the Past
description: The pioneering pop singer talks beauty secrets, and a life-changing tweezing session.
content: Debbie Gibson, the pop singer who shot to fame in the late 1980s with “Electric Youth,” is still making new music. She has an album out in August, “The Body Remembers,” her first in 20 years, and is performing in Las Vegas (at the Venetian) to boot. “Electric Youth” may have influenced fashion (her signature headwear) and beauty (Electric Youth perfume) for a certain generation, but Ms. Gibson, 50, is living firmly in the moment. “I never say ‘back in the day’ because today is today, and that’s how I approach life,” she said. Here, her current take on beauty products and wellness regimens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finn Cohen
title: The Enduring Appeal of Italian Composers’ Dramatic ‘Library Music’
description: Compositions made from the 1960s through the ’80s to soundtrack films and ads have found new homes on hip-hop tracks and compilations. New artists have been inspired, too.
content: One day in the summer of 2011, Lorenzo Fabrizi rode with a friend to an abandoned warehouse far outside of Rome. The custodian of the building, who said he had bought it for around $100, let them inside to look at its contents: 10,000 vinyl LPs, by Fabrizi’s estimate. They were welcome to take as many they wanted, the owner said; he was brewing beer in the space and had no use for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Government Warns Doctors and Insurers: Don’t Bill for Covid Vaccines
description: Such billing has been rare, but public concern about it may be contributing to hesitancy about getting the shot.
content: The New York Times is investigating the costs associated with coronavirus testing, treatment and vaccination. You can read more about the project and submit your medical bills here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: How Far Are Republicans Willing to Go? They’re Already Gone.
description: Forget Trump for a minute. The real action is taking place across the country in state capitols, mostly out of view.
content: Determined to enforce white political dominance in pivotal states like Georgia, Arizona, Texas and North Carolina, Republicans are enacting or trying to enact laws restricting the right to vote, empowering legislatures to reject election outcomes and adopting election rules and procedures designed to block the emergence of multiracial political majorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Atwood Lawrence
title: Was the Space Program Worth the Cost?
description: Jeff Shesol’s “Mercury Rising” explores the careers of John Kennedy and John Glenn as a way to cut through the rhetoric of space exploration.
content: MERCURY RISING

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. and Europe Look for Tariff Cease-Fire as Biden Heads Overseas
description: The Biden administration is trying to ease trade tension with allies, in part to help counter China.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States and the European Union are working toward an agreement that would settle long-running disputes over aircraft subsidies and metals tariffs that set off a trade war during the Trump administration as President Biden looks to re-engage with traditional American allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Kevins Can Score Improbably Attractive TV Wives
description: A new AMC+ satire mocks the family sitcom cliché of schlubby husbands paired with beautiful wives. Here are a few of the more egregious examples.
content: In 1998, during the second episode of the CBS sitcom “The King of Queens,” the husband, Doug (Kevin James), learns that the women in his wife’s family put on weight as they age. So even though Doug is fat — “I look like I’m in my twelfth trimester,” he says — he plots to keep Carrie (Leah Remini, a knockout then and now) slim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Park Police Had Planned to Clear Area Before Trump’s Walk to Church, Watchdog Says
description: The report by the Interior Department’s inspector general did not investigate what other law enforcement agencies knew and who might have ordered them to use force to clear Lafayette Square.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal watchdog said on Wednesday that the United States Park Police had been planning to clear protesters from a park near the White House well before they learned that President Donald J. Trump was going to walk through the area last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Reports of Severe Covid or Death After Vaccination Are Rare, but Not Unexpected
description: No vaccine is ever 100 percent effective, experts say, stressing that the shots remain critical in reducing severe disease and death from the coronavirus.
content: Over the last few months, a steady drumbeat of headlines has highlighted the astounding real-world effectiveness of the Covid-19 vaccines, especially the mRNA vaccines made by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna. The vaccines, study after study has shown, are more than 90 percent effective at preventing the worst outcomes, including hospitalization and death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: As a Family Is Mourned, Canada Grapples With Anti-Muslim Bias
description: After a driver intentionally ran down and killed a mother, father, daughter and grandmother in Ontario, orphaning a boy, there were calls for action against Islamophobia.
content: OTTAWA — With coronavirus restrictions still in place in much of Canada, many families have taken up going out together for evening strolls. On Sunday, however, a pleasant walk became the scene of a deadly attack by a motorist who used his truck to kill four members of a family in London, Ontario, and injure a boy who is now an orphan. They were targeted, the police said, because of their Muslim faith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The head of the Committee to Protect Journalists offers a warning as he prepares to step down.
description: Joel Simon, who will leave the organization after 15 years as executive director, says autocrats have become brazen in their efforts to block good journalism.
content: After 15 years as the executive director of the Committee to Protect Journalists, Joel Simon said on Wednesday that he would step down by the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Will College Athletes Make Money? Here’s Where the Debate Stands.
description: The financial realities for college athletes will dramatically change this summer. State governments, the N.C.A.A. and Congress all have a hand in shaping what that might look like.
content: College athletes are on the verge of being able to make money off their fame as the rules that have governed college sports for more than a century are upended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Johnson and Sergio Olmos
title: After a Year of Protests, Portland Is Ready to Move On. But Where?
description: The demonstrations that swept the country after George Floyd’s death lived on for much of the year in Portland, a city now engaged in finger-pointing and a debate over what comes next.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Defund the police? City leaders in Portland tried it. A unit in the fire and rescue bureau, one of the first of its kind in a major city, began this year taking some 911 calls about people in crisis, especially those who are homeless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: How Long Should It Take to Give Away Millions?
description: The promise of philanthropy was that the wealthy could enjoy tax breaks for their charitable contributions. The pandemic laid bare how accumulation can trump getting money to those in need. A Senate bill aims to change that.
content: The billionaires, former government officials and academics gathered in a Manhattan conference room to brainstorm solutions to a problem they had all been working on from various angles: how best to update the laws governing philanthropy, most of which were half a century old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kasia Pilat
title: 14 Strawberry Recipes Our Readers Make Over and Over Again
description: There are so many ways to enjoy the ruby-red summer berry, but these are the recipes that received top marks from our readers.
content: In “The Bluest Eye,” Toni Morrison writes, “I have only to break into the tightness of a strawberry, and I see summer.” The berry is a perfect complement to warm summer months — sweet but not cloyingly so, with a mellow tartness that sings alongside citrus or cream. Strawberries also play nicely with an array of different flavors and preparations, though you’ll have to resist eating them all straight out of the carton first. What follows are 14 of our readers’ most-loved strawberry recipes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Uber and Lyft Ramp Up Legislative Efforts to Shield Business Model
description: Gig economy companies are backing state laws in New York and elsewhere that would cement drivers’ status as contractors in exchange for a union.
content: After California passed a law in 2019 that effectively gave gig workers the legal standing of employees, companies like Uber and Lyft spent some $200 million on a ballot initiative exempting their drivers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada plans a first, and small, step for easing border restrictions.
description: Fully vaccinated Canadians — of which there are relatively few — will be able to skip a mandatory hotel stay when they get back home, but no firm date has been set for the change.

content: Stuart Silver, who as the inventive design director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the 1960s and ’70s turned the presentation of art into a gasp-inducing genre of theater, giving the staid institution mass appeal and inspiring widespread changes in the style and spirit of museum exhibitions, died on May 6 in Manhattan. title: Biden to Send 500 Million Doses of Pfizer Vaccine to 100 Countries Over a Year

content: It seems fairly unlikely that when Irwin Shaw wrote “The Girls in Their Summer Dresses,” his classic paean to “a million wonderful women, all over the city,” drifting along the pavement as warm breezes tugged at their hems, he could have envisioned a day when those “girls” would as likely be men. content: Good morning. title: On a Kentucky Riverbank, a Path to Remembrance

content: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Sometimes Hannah Drake stands at the banks of the Ohio River in Louisville, closes her eyes and tries to conjure the faces and stories of enslaved women, men and children who stood on that same land. What were they dreaming of as they looked across the river — just a mile wide in some places, far less in others — to Indiana, toward freedom? In New York and several other cities, parade organizers have said uniformed police officers may not march as a group.
